title-group.article-title: Simple technique using ridge spreaders to safely perform a transcrestal sinus floor elevation: a technical note

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, National Dental Centre Singapore, Singapore
2National Dental Research Institute Singapore, National Dental Centre Singapore, Singapore
3Discipline of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Faculty of Dentistry, National University of Singapore, Singapore
4Oral Health Academic Clinical Programme, Duke-NUS Medical School, Singapore

author-notes.corresp: Jonas Hue, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, National Dental Centre Singapore, 5 Second Hospital Avenue, 168938, Singapore, TEL: +65-6324-8802, E-mail: jonas.hue.j.j@ndcs.com.sg, ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5688-6160

abstract.p: Transcrestal sinus floor elevation (tSFE) is a useful method for vertical bone augmentation in the posterior maxilla at the time of implant placement. However, this is a blind surgical technique with a risk of perforating the Schneiderian membrane. In this article, we present a simple technique to perform tSFEs using ridge spreaders. With this technique, the tSFE is performed in a slow and controlled manner without the entry of instruments into the maxillary sinus. Furthermore, many clinicians may find they already have the necessary surgical tools within their armamentarium. This precludes the need for rotary drills that spin at high revolutions per minute in the sinus cavity or osteotomes which may result in an uncomfortable patient experience. In order to fully exemplify its clinical utility in performing successful tSFE without membrane perforation, we present this surgical technique in a case with limited residual bone height and a steeply oblique sinus floor.

sec.title: I. Introduction
sec.p: The posterior maxilla presents unique challenges to clinicians intending to restore function with dental implants due to the presence of the maxillary sinus. The sites of extracted premolars and molars often lack sufficient vertical bone height due to post-extraction bone resorption and pneumatisation of the sinus. The lateral window and transcrestal sinus floor elevation (tSFE) are two techniques that can be employed for vertical bone augmentation in the posterior maxilla1,2.

When residual subantral bone height (RBH) is at least 4 mm3, simultaneous vertical augmentation via tSFE and implant placement can be performed. Schneiderian membrane perforation has been reported to be the most common complication when performing tSFEs4 with risk factors such as limited RBH and uneven sinus floor morphology5. tSFE can be performed with osteotomes, rotary drills, osseodensification burs and piezoelectric surgery6. While some of these methods aim to reduce the risk of membrane perforation, none are immune to this surgical complication.

Clinicians have a variety of tools in their armamentarium when performing implant surgeries. Ridge spreaders are self-tapping, handpiece-mounted tools that are used at very slow speeds without irrigation. They can be found in many existing implant surgical kits and are typically used in situations with very dense bone where an undersized osteotomy would not allow an implant to be placed to depth at the appropriate torque. In this case, we utilize the ridge spreader without expanding the osteotomy to perform the tSFE and place the implant simultaneously with adequate torque.

In this article, we describe a technique of using ridge spreaders—also known as bone taps—to safely perform a tSFE with simultaneous implant placement. To the best of our knowledge, the use of ridge spreaders to perform tSFEs have not been described before.

sec.title: 1. Pre-operative planning and cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) analysis
sec.p: The technique is described using the example of an edentulous site of the upper right second premolar which was planned for replacement with a Ø4.0×8.0 mm implant (SuperLine; Dentium). A pre-operative CBCT was taken to assess the maxillary sinus morphology7 and alveolar bone for surgical planning. The RBH was 4.10 mm with a steeply oblique sinus floor.(Fig. 1. A-1. C) RBH of less than 5 mm has been identified as a risk factor for Schneiderian membrane perforation during tSFE8. In addition, some authors have cautioned against the use of osteotomes in steeply angled sinus floors due to the risk of membrane perforation5.

When measured 10.00 mm from the alveolar crest, the sinus width was 12.59 mm (Fig. 1. D), classified as wide according to the threshold of Stacchi et al.9. This was found to be associated with increased difficulty in achieving new bone formation and increased graft resorption10.

sec.title: 2. tSFE surgical procedure
sec.p: A full-thickness flap is raised and the osteotomy is prepared to a depth that is 0.5-1.0 mm beneath the sinus floor. The authors recommend the use of drill stoppers to prevent over or under-drilling. An over-drilled osteotomy risks perforating the Schneiderian membrane. On the other hand, an under-drilled osteotomy with too much apical bone will prevent successful lifting of the sinus floor. A radiograph with the final drill in the osteotomy is taken to check the drilling depth and ensure the sinus floor is intact.(Fig. 2. A)

The osteotomy–with intact sinus floor–is packed with the graft material of choice (Bio-Oss; Geistlich, 0.25-1.00 mm granules were used). A ridge spreader (SlimLine Surgical Kit; Dentium) of similar diameter to the prepared osteotomy is selected. In this case, the final drill has a diameter of 3.35 mm and a ridge spreader of 3.40 mm (RS351036R) is selected. The handpiece-mounted ridge spreader is used at 20 revolutions per minute (rpm) and 35 Ncm torque without irrigation. The self-tapping ridge spreader engages the walls of the osteotomy, sealing in the graft particles. A slow and controlled apical pressure is applied by the ridge spreader with graft particles cushioning the apex of the ridge spreader as it advances apically and performs the tSFE.(Fig. 2. B) The ridge spreader is used to the depth of the prepared osteotomy, never entering the sinus, and reversed out. This step is repeated until sufficient bone graft has been packed into the sinus.(Fig. 2. C) The ridge spreader should be mounted on a handpiece to prevent risk of displacement into the sinus. The implant is placed with a primary stability of 45 Ncm torque and a post-operative radiograph taken.(Fig. 2. D)

sec.title: 3. Post-operative follow-up
sec.p: The patient is recalled 6 months later and a post-operative CBCT is taken showing a successful vertical bone augmentation.(Fig. 3) Bone completely surrounds the apex of the implant with a cortical layer at the base of the sinus. The implant is uncovered and restored with a screw-retained crown.(Fig. 4)

sec.title: 1. Biomechanics and evidence supporting the technique
sec.p: The safety and viability of the technique we have described is supported by other tSFE methods which employ similar biomechanics. The biomechanics of our technique is similar to that described by Fettouh et al.11 which utilised the insertion of the dental implant to perform the tSFE. This technique also reported promising results with no complications, including sinus membrane perforation and 100% implant survival. However, our technique has the advantage of allowing the clinician to utilise biomaterials and the ridge spreader can be reversed out with repeated packing of bone graft particles depending on the amount of vertical bone augmentation required. This is achieved by using a ridge spreader of smaller diameter than the final implant to maintain a sufficiently undersized osteotomy to ensure primary stability during implant insertion.

Another method for tSFE with similar mechanics to our technique is the screwable osteotome12. This utilises a hand instrument that is manually screwed to fracture the sinus floor. Out of 98 patients, none had Schneiderian membrane perforation or benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), overall carrying lower morbidity than the mallet osteotomes. However, the screwable osteotomes are not widely available internationally with very few manufacturers supplying such equipment, making them less accessible than ridge spreaders.

sec.title: 2. Advantages over existing techniques
sec.p: The technique we describe in this article has several advantages over existing techniques. Osteotomes are used with malleting force to perform greenstick fractures of the sinus floor. This carries a risk of BPPV13 and membrane perforation particularly with oblique sinus floors5. Our technique applies a slow, controlled and continuous force, reducing the risk of membrane perforation while also removing the potential discomfort for the patient.

Rotary drill kits and osseodensification burs often require the drills to enter the sinus slightly at high rpm. When the floor of the maxillary sinus is oblique, a portion of the drill will rotate within the sinus before the entire sinus floor is elevated, potentially tearing the Schneiderian membrane. With our method, the ridge spreader does not need to enter the sinus. If it inadvertently enters the sinus cavity, the ridge spreader only rotates at 20 rpm and will have a layer of graft particles apically to act as a cushion.

Another advantage of our technique is that it uses tools that come from existing commercial surgical kits. Several other implant systems have their equivalent of ridge spreaders, sometimes called bone taps (e.g., BLT Taps [Straumann] and Tapered Bone Tap [BioHorizons]). These may already be within the armamentarium of many clinicians, allowing them to use this technique at no additional costs.

Sinus membrane perforation during tSFE is one of the most common surgical complications4 and can result in various issues. The patient may develop post-operative acute or chronic sinusitis and graft material displaced into the sinus may require further treatment14. Furthermore, membrane perforation may be associated with early implant failure15. The described technique may reduce the incidence of Schneiderian membrane perforation, especially in cases where anatomy may be particularly challenging. This also reduces the need for lateral window SFE which is more invasive with increased morbidity16,17. Overall, this technique may improve the success of vertical bone augmentation and implant survival with less risks to the patient.

sec.title: 3. Limitations
sec.p: While our method confers advantages over some of the existing tSFE techniques, there are also some limitations. Choosing the right sized ridge spreader is imperative for successful treatment. Implant drill sizes depending on the system used have to be matched to the diameter of the ridge spreader selected to maintain a sufficiently undersized osteotomy for primary stability of the implant. Depending on the implant system and ridge spreaders available to the clinician, there may not always be a perfect match to allow this technique to be employed. We encourage clinicians to check equipment catalogs carefully when planning for such procedures.

Although our technique aims to reduce certain surgical risks, it is certainly not flawless nor devoid of surgical complications. Clinicians should continue to check for intraoperative complications such as membrane perforations and address them as they would with other tSFE techniques. The approach taken depends on when the perforation occurs and may involve the use of short implants, converting to a graftless procedure or a lateral window SFE with membrane perforation repair18.
Lastly, while this technique has shown promising results, further clinical studies with larger cohorts are required to benchmark this method against other established tSFE techniques.

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: In this technical note, we present for the first time, the use of ridge spreaders to safely perform tSFEs. Our simple technique uses existing tools from readily accessible surgical kits from commonly used implant systems. Therefore, this technique can be easily employed in clinical practice. Our technique is minimally invasive and able to successfully perform tSFEs in spite of challenging anatomy. Furthermore, this technique has the advantage of being more comfortable to the patient with no risk of BPPV and no need for instruments to enter the sinus cavity.

fn.p: J.H. performed the operative procedure and prepared the figures and diagrams in the manuscript. J.H. and T.J.H.S. conducted a review of the literature. All authors, J.H., L.S., T.J.H.S. and B.T.G. were involved in writing and revision of the manuscript. L.S. and B.T.G. provided critical review and supervision of the work. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this article and accompanying images.
No potential conflict of interest relevant to this article was reported.

caption.p: A, B. Pre-operative cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) showing residual subantral bone height of 4.10 mm. C. Oblique sinus floor morphology at site of planned implant placement. D. CBCT showing buccopalatal sinus width measured at 10.00 mm from the alveolar crest.

A. Osteotomy prepared to a depth of 3.5 mm. Radiograph with final drill in osteotomy to check for appropriate drilling depth. B. Diagrammatic description of transcrestal sinus floor elevation (tSFE) technique with bone graft placed in osteotomy. C. Use of the ridge spreader at 20 rpm to perform the sinus floor elevation and pack graft material into the sinus. D. Immediate post-operative radiograph showing successful tSFE with dome-shaped radio-opaque bone graft.

A, B. Six months post-operative cone-beam computed tomography showing successful vertical bone augmentation with the transcrestal sinus floor elevation technique. The apex of the implant is completely surrounded by bone with a layer of cortical bone seen at the sinus floor.
Eight months after the transcrestal sinus floor elevation and simultaneous implant placement, the implant is restored with a screw-retained crown.
